'''Buster Pickens''' (June 3, 1916 – November 24, 1964)<ref name="Dead">{{cite web|author=Doc Rock |url=http://www.thedeadrockstarsclub.com/1960.html |title=The 1960s |publisher=The Dead Rock Stars Club |date= |accessdate=2013-11-21}}</ref> was an [[United States|American]] [[blues]] [[pianist]]. Pickens is best known for his work accompanying [[Alger "Texas" Alexander]] and [[Lightnin' Hopkins]], although he did record a solo album in 1960.

==Life and career==
He was born '''Edwin Goodwin Pickens''' in [[Hempstead, Texas|Hempstead]], [[Texas]].<ref name="TSHA"/><ref name="Ford">{{cite book
| first= Robert
| last= Ford
| year= 2007
| title= A Blues Bibliography
| edition= 2nd
| publisher= Taylor & Francis Group
| location= New York
| page= 8002
| isbn= 0-415-97887-4}}</ref>

In the 1930s Pickens, along with [[Robert Shaw (blues musician)|Robert Shaw]] and others, was part of the "Santa Fe Circuit", named after touring musicians utilising the [[Santa Fe, Texas|Santa Fe]] freight trains.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://sundayblues.org/archives/33 |title=Texas Piano Blues - 1920’s & 1930’s Part 5 | Big Road Blues |publisher=Sundayblues.org |date=2007-08-02 |accessdate=2013-11-21}}</ref>  From that time, Pickens described people doing the [[slow drag (dance)|slow drag]] to "slow low-down dirty blues" in [[Bar (establishment)|barrelhouse]] joints.<ref>''Jazz Dance: The Story of American Vernacular Dance'' by Marshall Winslow Stearns, Jean Stearns. 1994. Da Capo Press. p.23. ISBN 0-306-80553-7</ref>

Following service in the [[United States Army]] in [[World War II]], Pickens returned to [[Houston]], Texas.<ref name="TSHA"/> He appeared on his first [[Gramophone record|disc]] recording on January 13, 1948, providing backing for Perry Cain on his [[single (music)|single]] "All The Way From Texas" / "Cry Cry", released by [[Gold Star Records]]. Further recording work followed over the next eighteen months, as he played on different sessions as part of the accompaniment to Cain, [[Bill Hayes (actor)|Bill Hayes]], and [[Goree Carter]].<ref name="Wirz">{{cite web|url=http://www.wirz.de/music/pickefrm.htm |title=Buster Pickens discography |publisher=Wirz.de |accessdate=2013-11-21}}</ref>

Pickens later recorded for Freedom Records in 1950, playing accompaniment to [[Alger "Texas" Alexander]] on the latter's final recording session.  Pickens later performed live on a regular basis with [[Lightnin' Hopkins]], and played on several of Hopkins's [[album]]s in the early 1960s, including ''Walkin' This Road By Myself'' (1962), ''Smokes Like Lightning'' (1963), ''Lightnin' and Co.'' (1963).<ref name="Wirz"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.concordmusicgroup.com/albums/How-Many-More-Years-I-Got/ |title=How Many More Years I Got : Lightnin' Hopkins |publisher=Concord Music Group |date= |accessdate=2013-11-21}}</ref> Pickens had by this time also recorded his own debut solo album, ''Buster Pickens'' (1960), and appeared in the 1962 [[film]], ''The Blues''.<ref name="TSHA"/>

Pickens was shot dead, following an argument in a [[bar (establishment)|bar]] in Houston, in November 1964.<ref name="Dead"/><ref name="TSHA">{{cite web |first= |last= |url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/PP/fpi44.html|title=Buster Pickens|author=Bonura, Larry S|publisher=[[Texas State Historical Association]]|accessdate=January 31, 2010}}</ref>

==Discography==
*''Buster Pickens'' (1960) - [[Heritage Records (Australia)|Heritage Records]]<ref name="Album">{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/buster-pickens-mw0001882949 |title=Buster Pickens - Buster Pickens | Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2013-11-21}}</ref>
The album, recorded in Houston by [[Chris Strachwitz]], Mack McCormick and [[Paul Oliver]], comprised - "Santa Fe Train" / "Rock Island Blues" / "Ain't Nobody's Business" / "Colorado Springs Blues" / "She Caught the L & N" / "Remember Me" / "Women in Chicago" / "The Ma Grinder, No. 2" / "You Better Stop Your Woman (From Ticklin' Me Under the Chin)" / "Jim Nappy" / "Mountain Jack" / "D.B.A. Blues" / "Hattie Green" / "Backdoor Blues" / "Santa Fe Blues".<ref name="Wirz"/><ref name="Album"/>
